questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a stab injury to the abdomen presents to the casualty. Examination reveals abdominal tenderness and guarding. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The next best step in the management of a stab injury leading to features of peritonitis is emergency laparotomy.

  • The evaluation of penetrating abdominal trauma requires a structured approach, beginning with airway and breathing assessment, followed by identification of injuries.
  • Positive FAST may indicate the need for exploration, but it cannot rule out major bleeding.
  • For stab wounds, unstable patients with peritonitis or evisceration need immediate laparotomy, while stable patients may undergo wound exploration, ultrasound, CT, or laparoscopy depending on the location. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • Flank or back stab wounds often require contrasted CT, and left upper quadrant injuries may necessitate laparoscopy for diaphragmatic assessment.
  • Anterior stab wounds may be observed or discharged if no fascial penetration is present, but any suspected penetration warrants serial examinations or further imaging.
  • Diagnostic laparoscopy is accurate for detecting peritoneal violation but is user-dependent.
  • Development of peritonitis, hemodynamic instability, anaemia, or leukocytosis demands prompt laparotomy to systematically explore the abdomen and repair injuries.
  • The abdomen is opened widely for exposure, with division of the falciform ligament and use of retractors and sponges to aid hemostasis and visualisation.
  • The gastrointestinal tract, stomach, pancreas, and lesser sac are carefully inspected. Injuries are repaired, but physiologic deterioration may necessitate abbreviated damage control surgery with temporary abdominal closure.
  • When feasible, definitive closure is achieved, with subcutaneous wounds addressed based on intra-abdominal contamination.
  • The algorithm for the evaluation and management of abdominal stab wounds is illustrated below.

questions.text: A 25-year-old with a 5-year history of unilateral varicose veins on the left leg presents to the surgery OPD as shown below. Identify the correct statement regarding this condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the true statement regarding varicose veins, which arises due to venous hypertension, is that it can lead to eczema and pigmentation.

  • Varicose veins are dilated superficial veins that can be classified as uncomplicated or complicated.
  • Complications may include thrombophlebitis, bleeding, or venous ulcers. While some cases remain asymptomatic, others present with noticeable symptoms.
  • It is seen more commonly in women compared to men, and the prevalence increases with age.
  • Higher BMI and taller stature are linked with a greater risk and are also associated with long periods of standing.
  • Symptoms include aching, heaviness, throbbing, burning, or bursting sensations in affected limbs, worsening with prolonged standing and easing with elevation or compression.
  • Other common complaints are itching, ankle swelling, and vague venous discomfort
  • These symptoms may interfere with work, recreation, and caregiving, reducing quality of life.
  • Clinically, varicose veins appear as enlarged, twisted subcutaneous veins.
  • Duplex ultrasound scanning is the gold standard, replacing older methods.
  • Venous hypertension of the leg presents with multiple characteristic features, including varicose veins, telangiectasia, and oedema.
  • Other manifestations include eczema, which may start as mild erythematous dermatitis with itching but can advance to blistering and weeping.
  • Pigmentation (haemosiderosis) manifests as brown discolouration of the skin, usually permanent and often seen near varicose veins and incompetent perforators.
  • Lipodermatosclerosis (LDS) results from chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, producing a tight, woody leg on examination and occasionally leading to Achilles tendon contractures.
  • The CEAP system (Clinical-Aetiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) is a widely used descriptive classification for categorising chronic venous disorders and is given below.

Explanation of other options:

The most common cause is pelvic tumours (Option A): Pelvic tumours are not the most common cause of varicose veins. Other common risk factors include female sex, multiparity, obesity, and prolonged standing.

Graded as C6 (Option B): The image does not show an active venous ulcer, and so this option can be ruled out.

Recommended treatment is sclerotherapy in all cases (Option C): Sclerotherapy is not the recommended treatment in all cases.

questions.text: Identify the stage of breast cancer depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows diffuse erythema (covering more than 1/3rd of the breast) with peau d'orange.

  • Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, accounting for about one-fourth of all female cancers.
  • Risk factors are divided into modifiable and non-modifiable.
  • Increased estrogen exposure, nulliparity, late pregnancy, and high-risk breast lesions also raise susceptibility. Protective factors include prolonged breastfeeding.
  • Pathologically, breast carcinoma usually arises from ducts (90%) or lobules (10%), beginning as in situ disease and progressing to invasive carcinoma.
  • The Bloom-Richardson grading system classifies tumours based on tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic activity.
  • Variants like mucinous, medullary, and tubular carcinoma often have better prognoses. Molecular classification identifies luminal A, luminal B, HER2-enriched, basal-like, and claudin-low subtypes based on receptor status and proliferation index.
  • Cancer spreads locally into breast tissue and skin, producing signs such as dimpling, puckering, or nipple retraction, and through lymphatics to axillary or internal mammary nodes.
  • Hematogenous spread often involves bones, lungs, liver, and brain, with bone lesions being osteolytic or mixed.
  • Clinically, a breast lump is the most frequent presentation, commonly in the upper outer quadrant, with other features including nipple discharge, retraction, peau d'orange, and skin ulceration.
  • Advanced cases may show extensive infiltration of breast skin (cancer en cuirasse) or systemic symptoms due to metastases.
  • Staging is performed using the AJCC TNM system, which considers tumour size, nodal involvement, and metastasis, along with histological grade.
  • In addition, it also takes into account the receptor status (ER, PR, HER2), Ki-67 proliferation index, and molecular testing such as Oncotype DX®.

Explanations of other options:

T4b (Option A): Characterised by ulceration or satellite nodules/oedema of skin (including peau d'orange) not meeting criteria for inflammatory carcinoma.

T4c (Option C): Extension to the chest wall along with features of T4b.

T3 (Option D): Marked by tumour size greater than 5 cm.

questions.text: The fistula marked in the image given below is of which type according to the Park classification?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The arrow in the image points to a transsphincteric fistula according to the Park classification.

  • Fistula-in-ano is caused by a persistent tract between the anal canal (internal opening) and the perianal skin (external opening), often following drainage of a perianal abscess.
  • Patients experience recurrent pain, swelling, and relief after drainage. Examination usually reveals one or more external openings, sometimes with granulation tissue.
  • Multiple openings or a watering can perineum may suggest perianal Crohn's disease.
  • MRI can be used when the tract's course is unclear, helping to map openings and anatomy.
  • Fistulas are classified into four types based on the Park classification and are shown in the image below. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
    • Intersphincteric
    • Tanssphincteric,
    • Suprasphincteric
    • Extrasphincteric types
  • Treatment goals are to eradicate infection, remove epithelialized tracts, avoid faecal incontinence, and prevent recurrence. 
  • During surgery, identifying the fistula’s course is crucial. Goodsall’s rule can help predict the path.
  • External openings anterior to the anus usually track straight into the canal, unless they are >3 cm away, which often indicates a horseshoe extension.
  • Posterior external openings usually follow a curved tract to the posterior midline internal opening.
  • Anoscopy can detect erythematous crypts or internal openings. Probing or injecting substances like hydrogen peroxide, methylene blue, or milk into the tract can help visualise its path.
  • The anal mucosa must also be assessed to rule out causes like Crohn's disease, atypical ulcers, or malignancy.
  • Short and simple fistulas may be treated by fistulotomy (lay-open technique), which heals well and rarely causes incontinence.
  • Complex fistulas involving more sphincter muscle may first be managed with setons (silastic loops or rubber bands) to drain infection and maintain tract patency.
  • The ideal treatment closes the internal opening and eliminates all tracts without dividing the sphincter muscle.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient had an RTA and was initially conscious but later became unconscious and subsequently died. On postmortem examination, multiple petechial haemorrhages were seen in the corpus callosum, but no significant findings were seen on CT brain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features given of becoming unconscious after initially being conscious, with no changes on CT brain, but postmortem findings of multiple petechial haemorrhages in the corpus callosum, is suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

  • Diffuse axonal injury refers to damage to axons away from the neuronal cell body caused by rotational acceleration-deceleration trauma affecting the brain’s white matter tracts, leading to structural or functional disruption.
  • It arises due to the disruption of axoplasmic flow. It can also occur due to sudden angular acceleration, such as blast injuries, even without a direct skull impact.
  • Radiological imaging usually underrepresents the extent of this injury as most lesions are microscopic, often showing only punctate haemorrhages and loss of grey-white matter differentiation.
  • DAI severity is graded:
    • Grade I involves peripheral gray-white matter junctions
    • Grade II affects the corpus callosum, especially the splenium and posterior body
    • Grade III extends to the dorsolateral midbrain or brainstem.
  • Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) is the most sensitive technique for identifying acute, nonhemorrhagic DAI, with lesions showing hyperintensity on DWI and hypointensity on ADC.
  • Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) is highly effective for detecting associated microhemorrhages, as shown below.
  • Clinically, it is often recognised when patients present with significant neurological impairment despite relatively mild imaging findings, and predicting long-term outcomes remains challenging.

It is considered a major cause of loss of consciousness in patients without mass lesions and may occur alone or in combination with other injuries, like epidural or subdural hematomas.

  • Microscopically, it is marked by axonal swelling and focal hemorrhagic lesions.
  • These swellings can be detected using silver impregnation or immunohistochemical stains for axonal proteins like amyloid precursor protein and α-synuclein. These axonal retraction balls appear as shown below.
  • Over time, microglial proliferation occurs in the affected cortical regions, followed by degeneration of the damaged fibre tracts.

Explanation of other options:

Subarachnoid haemorrhage (Option A): Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, most often due to rupture of an arterial aneurysm, less commonly from arteriovenous malformations, or sometimes with no identifiable cause. CT scan shows hyperdense blood in basal cisterns or diffusely in the subarachnoid space, often extending into ventricles.

Subdural hematoma (Option C): Refers to bleeding between the dura mater and arachnoid mater, typically from the tearing of veins that traverse the subdural space. Characterised by a "comma" shape on axial CT, as shown below.

Extradural hematoma (Option D): Extradural hematoma is commonly associated with a fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone and is marked by a biconvex density on CT, as shown below.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5204088/

questions.text: Identify the type of bile duct injury shown in the image based on the Strasberg classification.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The bile duct injury shown in the image is consistent with type A bile duct injury according to the Strasberg classification.

  • The majority of bile duct injuries occur during cholecystectomy, with factors such as anatomical variations, porta hepatis inflammation, poor exposure, limited surgical skill, and aggressive hemostasis contributing to the risk.
  • Misidentification of anatomy, for example, cystic duct being mistaken for the common hepatic duct, is a common cause.
  • Inadequate traction and failure to achieve the critical view of safety increase the risk
  • Clinically, injuries manifest as bile leakage or stricture, with leakage often leading to peritonitis and presenting earlier than stricture.
  • Patients may also develop fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice.
  • The original analysis of biliary reconstruction was based on the Bismuth classification and has been modified by Strasberg. Classification of bile duct injuries is determined by location and helps guide later surgical reconstruction, and is given below.

questions.text: A patient with jaundice, anorexia, and weight loss for 2 months. The gall bladder is palpable, soft and non-tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of a soft, palpable, non-tender gallbladder associated with jaundice and weight loss is pancreatic head cancer.

  • Pancreatic cancer risk is influenced by both environmental and hereditary factors. Smoking is the strongest environmental risk, with incidence directly proportional to the number of cigarettes smoked, while obesity and diabetes (especially new-onset diabetes) are also associated.
  • Chronic pancreatitis, occupational exposures, and long-term diabetes may further increase risk.
  • Hereditary syndromes associated with pancreatic cancer include:
    • Familial pancreatic cancer
    • Hereditary pancreatitis (PRSS1, SPINK1)
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
    • Cystic fibrosis (CFTR mutation)
    • Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome (CDKN2A mutation)
    • BRCA2 mutations
    • Lynch syndrome
    • Familial adenomatous polyposis
  • Pathogenesis involves progression from pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN) to invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), with mutations in KRAS, CDKN2A/p16, TP53, and SMAD4 driving tumour development.
  • Pancreatic cancer commonly presents late, with symptoms such as jaundice, weight loss, nausea, pruritus, and, rarely, gastrointestinal bleeding.
  • Courvoisier's law states that a shrunken fibrotic non-palpable gallbladder, along with jaundice, is suggestive of choledocholithiasis, while a palpable gallbladder points to a periampullary mass such as cancer of the head of the pancreas.
  • Diagnosis involves laboratory evaluation, tumour markers like CA 19-9 (sensitive but not specific), and imaging.
  • EUS (Endoscopic ultrasound) with FNA offers high diagnostic accuracy, MRCP provides detailed biliary anatomy, and FDG-PET combined with CT aids in differentiating benign from malignant lesions and detecting occult disease.
  • Treatment depends on the tumour location.
    • For head tumours, pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) is the standard, involving removal of the pancreatic head, duodenum, gallbladder, and bile duct, followed by reconstruction.
    • For body and tail tumours, distal pancreatectomy with splenectomy is performed, with medial-to-lateral or antegrade dissection approaches.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (Option A): Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) often presents with features resembling cirrhosis, including jaundice, spider angiomas, ascites, and splenomegaly. About one-fourth of patients develop metastases to sites such as lymph nodes, lungs, bone marrow, and brain, while splenomegaly may lead to anaemia, thrombocytopenia, or pancytopenia. A palpable gallbladder rules against this diagnosis.

Gall bladder cancer (Option B): Gallbladder cancer usually remains asymptomatic until advanced stages, with many patients presenting with systemic spread, including nodal involvement and distant metastases. Early signs may mimic acute or chronic cholecystitis, with recent change in the quality and frequency of pain, while late-stage disease often manifests as weight loss, jaundice, abdominal mass, and chronic epigastric pain.

Choledocholithiasis (Option D): Choledocholithiasis can present with biliary colic or obstructive jaundice, characterised by dark urine, scleral icterus, and pale stools. Jaundice is often painful due to acute obstruction, causing bile duct distention. Complications include cholangitis, presenting with Charcot's triad of right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice, which may progress to septic shock with altered mental status and hypotension known as Reynolds pentad.

questions.text: What is true about the procedure shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image depicts escharotomy, and the true statement regarding this procedure is that it is done in circumferential burns.

  • Escharotomy is performed when circumferential deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns restrict circulation or ventilation. (Option C ruled out)
  • In limbs, oedema under the rigid eschar obstructs venous outflow and eventually arterial inflow, leading to pain, numbness, and tingling.
  • Clinical signs, Doppler assessment, or compartment pressures above 30 mm Hg indicate the need for escharotomy.
  • The procedure involves longitudinal incisions through the burn eschar, usually on the medial and lateral aspects of extremities, to relieve constriction and restore perfusion.
  • For upper limbs, incisions may extend onto the thenar, hypothenar, and fingers.
  • In the chest, escharotomy is indicated when a circumferential burn restricts chest expansion and breathing.
  • Two longitudinal and two horizontal incisions are made to improve ventilation and oxygenation.
  • For the limbs, incisions are placed along the midaxial line to avoid major nerves. (Option D ruled out)
  • Complications include blood loss, release of anaerobic metabolites causing transient hypotension, reactive hyperemia with worsening oedema, and increased compartment pressures that may necessitate fasciotomy.
  • Because of bleeding risks, cutting diathermy and proper dressings are recommended during the procedure.

Explanation of other options:

The image shows a skin graft (Option B): The image shows escharotomy. Skin grafts are of two types: split-thickness and full-thickness. The image below shows a split-thickness graft.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with progressive non-retractable foreskin and tense, white preputial skin. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of progressive phimosis, along with the image showing white preputial skin, suggests a diagnosis of balanitis xerotica obliterans.

  • Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO), also known as lichen sclerosus (LS), is a chronic inflammatory condition of the foreskin, possibly autoimmune in origin, that may also extend to the distal urethra.
  • It is rare before five years of age and presents in boys with progressive phimosis, depigmentation and scarring of the prepuce, white indurated skin, dysuria, and ballooning during urination. The condition is characterised by fibrosis of the foreskin and sometimes involvement of the glans, producing white patches.
  • Complications include meatal stenosis and penile urethral strictures, which are often long and challenging to treat and hence continuous follow-up is essential.
  • LS can present in two phases: active and burnt out, with patients frequently showing poor urinary flow.
  • Diagnosis is usually clinical, but a biopsy provides confirmation.
  • Investigations such as uroflowmetry, retrograde urethrogram (RGU), and voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) aid in assessing urethral involvement.
  • Management typically requires circumcision, although topical corticosteroids may help in some cases.

Explanation of other options:

Recurrent balanoposthitis (Option A): Recurrent balanoposthitis is inflammation of the glans penis and foreskin caused by infection, irritation, or trauma. Symptoms include pain, itching, rash, dysuria, and non-urethral penile discharge. While most boys experience only one or two episodes requiring no treatment, repeated recurrences may warrant circumcision.

Urethral meatus stenosis (Option B): It is a complication of balanitis xerotica obliterans but since the image does not show meatal stenosis.

Paraphimosis (Option C): Paraphimosis occurs when the foreskin is pulled back behind the glans and cannot be moved forward again, leading to swelling and pain of the glans. If manual reduction is unsuccessful, urgent intervention with a dorsal slit or circumcision is required.
